Award.AbstractNarration: This project will support students to attend SustainIT conference to be held in Palermo, Italy on Oct 30-31, 2013. The SustainIT conference focuses on applications of information and communication technologies (ICT) for Sustainability. SustainIT 2013 will include Ph.D. forum, work in progress session, poster session, industry track and keynotes. Extended versions of selected papers will be published. The conference will provide an opportunity for students to interact with researchers, particularly computer scientists, working on applications of ICT for sustainability. The students will be selected based on applications that explain how they will benefit from the conference. Preference will be given to minority students and students with accepted papers in SustainIT.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This travel grant allowed to support seven US based students (including one female) on a competitive basis to travel attend International Conference on Sustainable Internet and ICT for Sustainability (SustainIT 2013) held in Palermo, Italy. The studnets came from MIT, Purdue University, Arizona State Uiversity, University of South Florida, University of Bridgeport, and Missouri Univ of Science and Technology. Without the travel support, most of these students would not have otherwise attended this conference of emerging importance.

 

Intellectual Merit:

The supported students to not only attend technical presentations at the conference but also exchanged ideas and shared experiences among peers, senior researchers, professionals, and application developers both from industry and academia.They also participated in the PhD Forum with poster presentation.They were more encouraged too take up academic or research career.

 

Braoder Impacts:

Participation in SustainIT 2013 conference was an extremely valuable experience of the seven US based graduate students (including one female student), providing the opportunity to interact with peers and senior researchers. They were also exposed to cutting-edge research in the field of sustainability. In particular, the female student supported by the tarvel grant was in the area of communications technology and social media. She was conducting research and working with a water conservation team based in Southwest Morocco. She built an information system through rural mountain villages. She also researched how to encourage women's participation in monitoring parts of the larger fogwater catchment device.
